author: timbeiko
content: Is there any easy way to know if a chain supports 1559 via JSON RPC?

author: sky.cactus
content: No.  There has been off and on talk about capability detection in the past, which this could fit into potentially, but nothing ever materializes.

author: sky.cactus
content: Similar to ERCs, we need a "committee" who drives the interface forward (like we discussed in EIPIP meeting).

author: timbeiko
content: I guess the "hacky" way to do it is call getBlockByNumber and see if it returns something with a base fee?

author: timbeiko
content: It will only tell you if the chain supports it _now_ but I'm not sure we have any way to query the node about future functionality anyways

author: sky.cactus
content: We don't have anything for that presently.

author: jochembrouwer
content: We could integrate the thing which we have on devp2p? https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2124

author: jochembrouwer
content: RPC would then give access to the values in this EIP, so you can check if the endpoint supports certain forks now, or will in the future. Although this only works for consensus breaking EIPs I guess. So not "soft" EIPs

author: timbeiko
content: This doesn't tell you if 1559 is enabled, though. It will tell you for _mainnet_ because we know 1559 is in London, but a separate network could decide to implement just 1559 and won't have the same fork ID as mainnet.
